Speaker: phil
Dialogue: T minus ten, nine, eight, start ignition sequence, five, four, three, two, one, ignition... Liftoff!

Speaker: children
Dialogue: My turn! My turn! No, I was next! No, me! Uncle Phil, Uncle Phil, can I do one? I want to do one!

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Guys, guys, please! This is risky stuff here. And I'm a highly trained professional.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Okay, okay! Uncle Phil will launch another booster...

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: ...just as soon as he completes his fuel intake.

Speaker: willis
Dialogue: It'll take us six months just to get to Mars. Another year on the surface, then six months back. That's two years...

Speaker: willis
Dialogue: I guess what I'm trying to say is, since this is my last night on Earth, it's gonna be a very precious memory to me. Y'know?

Speaker: pretty girl
Dialogue: Nice try, Nick.

Speaker: kirov
Dialogue: Hey, Woody, our Mars One crew won't be heading back to Earth till ten days after you guys land at our base camp with Mars Two. That's a pretty good long rendezvous.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: What are you suggesting, Sergei?

Speaker: kirov
Dialogue: Maybe you should bring a baseball bat. Yes? American baseball? Our two crews could have ourselves a little Solar System Series.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Please. Half you guys are foreigners. We'd crush you.

Speaker: kirov
Dialogue: No, no, we have equal crews. Three men, one woman. Same handicap.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Easy now, you're talking about my wife.  And Terri just happens to be one helluva shortstop.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Fast pitch, no steals, batter calls his own strikes. Thousand bucks make it interesting?

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: Eh bien. Winner take all.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Good.  Bring some balls.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: You wanna know the sad part? Technically I outrank her. But if we want any peace at all on Mars Two, I'm gonna be saying a lot of "Yes, dears."

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: All the research shows that marriage will provide stability on these long duration trips.

Speaker: debra
Dialogue: He's not coming, Luke.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Jim deserves this, too. All his friends are here. And it's my last night.

Speaker: debra
Dialogue: Your last night with us, too.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: I love you, Deb.

Speaker: debra
Dialogue: I love you too, baby. But maybe you should spend some time with Bobby.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Yeah. I will. Where is he?

Speaker: debra
Dialogue: Up in his fort.

Speaker: willis
Dialogue: Deep space is so lonesome. So cold. But I guess I'll have my memories to keep me warm...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Who's gonna read to me now, at bedtime?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Mommy will.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I like when you do it. Now we're never gonna finish our book.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Well, I'll tell you what. I've been thinking about that. And what I thought was -- how 'bout if I bring along my own copy?  Then every night, wherever I am, I'll read a little bit more of it. And I'll know that you and Mommy, wherever you are, you're reading it too. That way, it'll feel like we're still reading it together. 'Cause I don't know about you, but I'm pretty anxious to find out how 'ol Ben Gunn got marooned on that island. What d'you say?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Good deal. Can I have a hug?

Speaker: debra
Dialogue: We were afraid you wouldn't come.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I caught a whiff of your barbecue. After that I was helpless.

Speaker: debra
Dialogue: All the way out in Galveston?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Something like that.  It's his night, Deb. I didn't want to spoil it.

Speaker: debra
Dialogue: Spoil it? He's been going crazy looking for you.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: C'mon. A whole lot of folks here are gonna be mighty glad to see you.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: I wish we were all going. Together.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Then you've got a short memory. Think back to how we were by the second week of lunar training.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Oh, you're not gonna bring that up again --

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: I'm trying to remember, let's see, which one of us scored the lowest ranking up there?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: You just can't let that go --

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Oh, man, three commanders, on the same ship? If they sent us off to Mars together, there wouldn't be enough fuel to lift all those egos.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Bullshit, we would've made a great crew.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: That was never gonna happen. I was always teamed with Maggie, and we were mostly chalkboard jockies. You know? Systems. Payloads...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Listen to him. Mr. Cover-of-Time Magazine!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Yeah, who landed the crippled Block II Shuttle?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Yeah, and who scored highest on the lunar rankings?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Let it go, Luke.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: ...read too much science fiction as a kid and still wear little Flash Gordon rocketships around their necks.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: You read the same damn science fiction books that I did! You're just not man enough to wear jewelry!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: You want Flash. You know you want him. Well you'll have to come through me!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: God, she would've loved to see you two clowns. Just one more time.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Hey, Woodrow, isn't it about time you donated this thing to a museum?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Internal combustion, boys. Accept no substitutes.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Jim, if there's ever... if there's anything Terri and I can do --

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I'm okay. Really. Thanks.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: See you when I get to Mars, Luke. Don't solve all the mysteries of the universe, okay? Leave a little something for the next guys.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: I'll see what I can do. Just make sure you bring some fresh beer.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: You got it.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Should've been your mission, Jim. Yours and Maggie's.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: None of us ever wanted Mars the way you two did. Not even Woody. Twelve years of hoping for this assignment, training for it --

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: That's all over now.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: If Maggie hadn't gotten sick -- if you hadn't pulled yourself out of the rotation to take care of her --

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: No, I'm gonna say this. I have to say it...  I wanted Mars One. Hell, I battled you for it every step of the way. Never wanted to beat anybody so bad in my life. But not like this... Jim, I'd give this all up in a second, if it would bring Maggie back to us.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I know that, Luke. You don't have to say it... Mars is yours now. Go get it.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Take care of yourself.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Yeah. You too.

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: Luke, you read me?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Yeah, Renee.

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: Luke, I just got ARES-8 on line and... Well, we think you're gonna wanna see this for yourself.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Copy that.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: What the hell is that?

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: No idea, boss.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Where is it?

Speaker: willis
Dialogue: You don't wanna know.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: C'mon, what's so funny? Gimme the coordinates.

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: Latitude 41 degrees north, longitude 9 degrees west.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: The Plains of Cydonia. So?  Oh no. You're not telling me --

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: Oui. Exactement! It's Kirov's fault, he picked today's sector.

Speaker: kirov
Dialogue: Hey, c'mon! We've got a scientific duty to check that thing out.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Great. That's great. The first anomaly we hit, and it's gotta be in the one place guaranteed to make NASA look ridiculous... You know how many books have been written about that damned mountain?

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: The Egyptians put it there.

Speaker: kirov
Dialogue: No, the Amazons.

Speaker: willis
Dialogue: No, it was little green men!

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: And all because a couple of lousy impact craters happen to look like eye sockets. If this gets out, we'll have every UFO kook on Earth spouting off on the six o'clock news... C'mon, people, gimme a read here. Is that a cinder cone?

Speaker: kirov
Dialogue: Nah, too smooth. Too angular. Volcanic upwelling?

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: No fissures. No caldera.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: It's an upwelling, for sure. But maybe not volcanic...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Look at the color. And see how shiny it is? I could swear that's ice...

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: This far south?

Speaker: willis
Dialogue: Impossible. You can't have ice at this latitude. Not unless...

Speaker: willis
Dialogue: Oh my God.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: How far away is it?

Speaker: kirov
Dialogue: Sixteen kilometers northeast. Take us twenty minutes to get there.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Let's send a packet to Micker. Then we'll go check it out.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: This is a truly anomalous formation. Looks like nothing we've seen so far. The structure appears to be crystalline, at least from the angle displayed by ARES-8 ...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: We're all trying not to go too nuts up here, but -- we think there's a good chance this could be an extrusion from some subsurface, geothermal column of water. And if we're right...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: ...then we've found the key to permanent human colonization.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Tell geology and hydrology we need to scramble on this. Full-court press.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Anyway, we'are going out to take a closer look at it, try to get an idea of its composition.  By the time you receive this, we should be just about on-site.

Speaker: kirov
Dialogue: Jesus Christ...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Anyone else hear that?

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: Yeah. What is it?

Speaker: willis
Dialogue: Sounds like our antenna's out of phase.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Can you fix it?

Speaker: willis
Dialogue: Hey, skip, I can fix anything.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Big talker. Renee, Sergei, let's break out the radar, see what this thing's made of.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: ...and this is the Mars Mission Control Room, nicknamed "Micker." I understand a comm packet is incoming from Mars One Base Camp, so you may find this interesting.

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: That man over there. He's in charge?

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: No, actually, that's Jim McConnell, the CAPCOM. Our voice link to the astronauts? Jim's been with the manned Mars program since its inception. One of our real pioneers.

Speaker: ambassador
Dialogue: Will he be going to Mars, too?

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Ah, no. This is as close as he gets.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: ...anyway, that's about it. We'll send another packet when we get back.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Oh, right. One more thing. Today is a very special day for a good friend of ours, and I know he's there right now.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Now, he hates it when any fuss is made, so I won't mention his name...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: ...because the last thing in the world I'd ever want to do is embarrass someone like Jim McConnell.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: C'mon, you Micker weasels, sing!

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Hey, Ray! Take a look at him! Is he all red with one of those fake "I'm- a-good-sport" grins?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: And hey, you guys, check out Ray! Does he have on one of his "This- wasn't-in-my-mission-plan" faces?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Nothing you can do about it, Ray! We're a hundred million miles away!

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Happy Birthday, Jimbo! Make a wish!

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Catch you again soon. Take care, buddy. End of transmission.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Well? What's under there?

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: Je ne sais pas. I... I think there's something wrong with the equipment.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: I mean, it can't be right. It says... it says there's metal under there.

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: There's ten, twelve meters of rubble and sand, and then... solid metal.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: That doesn't make any sense. You're reading a vein of ore.

Speaker: cote
Dialogue: No. It's under the whole mountain.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Nick, could the problem with the antenna be interfering?

Speaker: willis
Dialogue: Could be.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Try it closer and up the power. I'll watch the screen.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Ah, we're all pretty stoked about that formation you spotted, Mars One. The folks in the geology and hydrology back rooms are going over your images and comparing them to every photomap they've got.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Nick, how we coming on that antenna?

Speaker: willis
Dialogue: Goin' as fast as I can, boss.

Speaker: kirov
Dialogue: Hey, Nick. Come show me how stupid I am. I can't get this to work.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Medical wants me to remind you that you're three days late on your blood tests. I know they're a bore, but you've got to get them done, or else... or else I don't know what. Just do them, okay?

Speaker: kirov
Dialogue: All set here, chief.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Okay. Crank up the juice and let's see what's in this sucker.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I think that's about it for business. But on a personal note, be advised that, ah, none of you can sing worth a damn.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Why did that stop?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Honestly, Luke, if you guys don't have anything better to do with your time, I can make some suggestions to mission medical. There are worse things than blood tests.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Oh, and I talked to Debra. She and Bobby are doing fine. Said to tell you, they're, ah, they're on their "third time through the book, page --  -- page 125." They send their love and say take care of yourself. Same from us here, buddy. Till next time, then. End of transmission.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: "Problem: Hatch door malfunction, backup power fail, manual override fail. Solution: Replace circuit breaker 907B."

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Okay... Piece of cake.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: God, who dreams up these nightmares?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Don't try to change the subject.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: I'm not! We're talking about your sister's wedding, right?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Very funny. We're talking about dancing lessons. Before my sister's wedding.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Honey, do you mind? I've got a catastrophic power failure here.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Woody, we're a married couple. Would it kill you to invite me out on the floor once in awhile?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: I danced with you at our wedding.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I'm not talking about shuffling your feet around while you grab my butt. I mean real dancing. Cha-cha, rhumba, jitterbug --

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Face it, honey, some couples dance, some go to Mars. That's life.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I'm serious. We've got two more months in this training rotation, but just as soon as we get home, we're starting lessons. If we never dance, people will think there's something wrong.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: If they see me dance, they'll know there's something wrong.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: You are such a lug.

Speaker: phil's voice
Dialogue: Cockpit, this is Control.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Control, this is Cockpit.

Speaker: phil's voice
Dialogue: Uh, Terri, they want us all back in the Station. Report to Micker.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Who says report to Micker?

Speaker: phil's voice
Dialogue: The little men who live in my head.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Phil, c'mon! We just started this drill.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Woody, it was Ray Beck. He told me to round up the team. Now.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Then, at 1417, the X-band continuous data stream from Mars went silent. All data -- med, environmental, everything -- suddenly stopped. While we were trying to figure out what the hell went wrong, we got a signal from the folks at the Large Array at Soccoro.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: At the same moment we lost the data stream, they picked up an intense burst of energy from Mars.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: What do you mean, "intense"?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Catastrophic.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: What about the crew?

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: The level of energy in the pulse... didn't seem survivable.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: What about the REMO? It went into Mars orbit last week. Maybe that could give us some clue.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Good thinking, Woody. That's just what we tried next.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: The Resupply Module checked out fine. No instrument failures, no change in status. Orbit holding steady. But there was something else. The REMO'S computer contained an uplink message -- a very faint, highly distorted transmission from Mars One Base Camp.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Someone's alive.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: The message is almost indecipherable. Two teams are still working on it. You better see for yourselves.

Speaker: technician
Dialogue: Still concentrating on the audio. We managed to bring out a couple more words, but we've got a long way to go.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Show us whatever you've got.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: ...make this quick... may be only ch--  ...to the site, when we... hit us just as we... --thers are all dead...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: ...--stems are holding up for now, but I don't know how long I can...

Speaker: technician
Dialogue: That's it.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: What did Luke mean by a "low sound?"

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: If this was a earthquake, as we're now assuming, there's usually an auditory component.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: But that energy pulse they picked up in New Mexico...

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Electromagnetic emission. Not uncommon with large-scale geophysical phenomena.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Causing this kind of damage? I don't buy it. We're missing something here.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Luke must be in pretty bad shape if he hasn't blasted out of there in the Earth Return Vehicle. That thing's designed so even one crew member could fly it back to Earth.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Even if Luke was in great shape, he couldn't get home. That energy pulse would've fried the ERV'S computers.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Other than the computers, how do we think the ERV fared?

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Well, so far our modelling says it should be in pretty good shape.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Which means it's gonna be up to us to get new motherboards, drives, and software to Mars. As fast as we can.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Whoa, slow down. It's gonna take us weeks just to analyze this data.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Right, but meanwhile, we've gotta be working up a mission plan.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Luke needs us now.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Luke may already be dead. And even if he's not, it's doubtful he's going to be able to transmit again. So we wouldn't know whether it's safe to land until you were almost there.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: What about SIMA?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: The Saturn Imaging Probe. It's going to slingshot around Mars on its way through the solar system. It could be retasked to take pictures, read radiation levels at Mars One Base Camp.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Good idea Phil. If SIMA tells us Luke hasn't survived and it's not safe to land, we swing around Mars and come right back home.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Yes. We can design the mission to have a free return capability. It's a long trip, but if you don't land it's the best option.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: We're getting ahead of ourselves. You're forgetting the bigger problem.  The orbits are all wrong. Our first decent launch window is almost eight months from now.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: But we can go earlier and get there faster if we reconfigure the payload for extra fuel. We've modelled that, Ray. I've modelled it.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: On paper, yeah. But those stresses have never been tested in space.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: The ship can take it.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: I wasn't thinking of just the ship.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I know the protocols for a Mars Recovery Mission better than anybody, because I helped design them. And I'm saying these guys can do it.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: He's right, Ray. We've got a real shot.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Give me an updated mission plan by 0800 tomorrow. Then I'll put it in the works.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Let's get to work.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Chief, could I have a word?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: I've no longer got the right crew.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: What do you mean? Bjornstrom can be up here on the next shuttle.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Bjornstrom is a geologist. He's good, but not for this. My people just lost eight months of training. This is a different mission, with a different objective.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: I haven't been given authorization for a mission yet.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: But when you are, it ought to be given the best chance for success. I want McConnell to fly right seat.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: He's no longer on mission status.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Yeah. Because you washed him out.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: He washed himself out. He only had to pass a few more psych evaluations, but he refused to take them.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Ray, he's the best pilot I ever saw, and you've got him benched at a desk.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Everybody has to pass the psych prelims. No exceptions. Jim knew that.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Maggie was his wife. He didn't want to lie on a couch and share her with strangers.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: That was his call. But I had to make one too. It was tough as hell, but I'd do it again.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: His wife wasted away in front of his eyes. What was he supposed to do? Suck it up? Get with the program? What was his crime? That he was upset? That he cried...?

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: I couldn't trust him!

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Not in a crisis... I'm sorry Woody, but Jim lost his edge. Are you gonna stand there and tell me Jim McConnell is the same man he was two years ago? You want me to bet four more lives on that?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: When Maggie died, yeah, it knocked the shit out of him. It knocked the hell out of all of us. But you know and I know that he's still the best we've got. He and Maggie wrote the book on Mars. He's got more hours in the sims than the rest of us put together. Ray, we can do this. Give me McConnell as co-pilot, and we will bring Luke home. And that's a promise.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: That... is the exact chemical composition of my ideal woman.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Used to be.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Now what is it?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: A frog.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I guess now we have our answer to the effects of long-term interplanetary travel on the human mind. The answer is Phil.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I'm gonna get an update on SIMA. It should be just about close enough to start capturing some surface images.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Hey, Skip.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Take a look.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: What do you make of that?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Dust storm. Southern hemisphere, coming from the east... Big fella, too.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Headed for Chryse Planitia.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Yup. Could get a little hairy just about landing time...

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: We'll have to be ready to move fast. Maybe even advance our ETA. Those things can cover the whole planet, and last up to a year.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: When does SIMA do her fly-by?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Tomorrow morning, about 0600. That's when we find out whether we came all this way for nothing.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: My money's on Luke.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: What brought this on?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Zero-G. My last chance to be graceful. Once we're in Mars gravity, it's back to shuffling my feet and grabbing her butt.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I'll take what I can get.

Speaker: computer
Dialogue: Attention. Incoming packet.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: It's SIMA.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Looks deserted.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: It's still standing, though. So is the ERV. And look, there's the greenhouse.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: We know Luke survived for at least a few hours. Question is, are there any signs of recent activity?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: There.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: What the hell are those?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Graves.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Hold on. There's only three. That means --

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Phil --

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: It means Luke must still be --

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: No. It just means there was nobody left to bury him.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Check the radiation levels.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Normal.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Go to the disaster site.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: What's wrong?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: I don't know. Magnetic interference?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Go to infrared.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Must be a problem with SIMA. I don't see how an earthquake, six months ago, could give us this kind of distortion.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: That was no quake.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Then what the hell was it?

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: We're going to continue analyzing this data and try to determine what the problem is with those images. Frankly, we're just as stumped as you guys, but we'll keep on it.  We agree that the evidence of the graves is inconclusive and that a ground search is advisable. Be aware there are little sand storms kicking up near Mars One Base, but the big one you spotted is turning south. It shouldn't be a factor.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: We're all pretty excited here and we're sure you must be feeling the same. Enjoy your meal and get a good night's sleep. We anticipate that tomorrow morning you will be Go for Mars Orbital Insertion.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: God bless you and goodnight. End of transmission.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: What if you opened up your meal packs and found that, instead of putting in everything but red ones, they'd made a mistake and put in only red ones?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Hey, that's a funny notion. And what if in your meal packs, instead of brown rice, there were spring-loaded spikes that shot into your eyes?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: How did you ever pass the psych evaluation?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: When you're schizophrenic, they take the higher score.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Jim's first ship was seriously underpowered...

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Maggie was always starstruck...

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: I'll get you guys for this.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: When they met at the Air Force Academy, it was "love at first flight."

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: After that, NASA training was tough. All Jim could think about was exploring a heavenly body. More ribald LAUGHTER, as

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: But Maggie, as you can see, kept him on a short leash. Until...

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Mission accomplished!

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Today we celebrate a new chapter in their story. And guys, it's a pretty historic one.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Let's hear it for the newly-announced Captain and Co-Captain of Mars One. To Jim and Maggie!

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: When you guys land, it'll prove once and for all there's no intelligent life on Mars.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: Hey, c'mon, what if I'm right?

Speaker: assorted voices
Dialogue: Oh no, here we go! Don't get her started! Somebody put on some music!

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: It's our sister planet!

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Oh brother!

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Maggie, why does this have to be about us? Mars is a great opportunity for pure science.

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: We'll do the science. And we'll do it very well. That's what we've trained for. But what if there's more...? In all our myths, in every human culture, Mars has always held a special attraction. What if that means something? Only we don't understand it yet...

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: The universe is not chaos. It's connection. Life reaches out for life...

Speaker: maggie
Dialogue: This is what we were born for, isn't it? To stand on a new world, and look beyond it to the next one. It's who we are.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: You okay?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Yeah. I'm good to go.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: After all these years... Can you believe it? Tomorrow we'll be standing on Mars.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: You know what? She may have been right.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: If that wasn't a quake down there, then something else caused it. Or planned it... You're thinking the same thing.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: It's never been out of my mind.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Jesus. You realize what this means?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: She knew, Woody. She was the only one of us that ever thought there might be something down there.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Yeah, and we're not leaving until we find out... Deal?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Maggie was the best of us.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Range 6783 and closing. 35 minutes till Mars Orbital Capture.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Okay, people let's look sharp. If we overshoot, there's no coming back.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Charge primary APU.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Select HPU fuel cells for run.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Tie main bus to systems.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Select H2/O2 HPU and fuel cells for open.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Charged and on-line

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Set

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Transfer protocol data from EVA station.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Transferred. Awaiting track confirmation.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Uhhh!

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: What in God's --

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Micrometeoroids

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Breach hits in the hull!

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Outgassing! Losing pressure!

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Woody, seal the breech!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Kill those alarms!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Still outgassing in the lower Hab! There must be another hole down there, even bigger.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Losing pressure fast! We're gonna decompress!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Computer, how long until zero atmosphere?

Speaker: computer
Dialogue: Four minutes, nine seconds.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: If we get below 20% atmosphere, the power will shut down!

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Are you sure?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Positive! A vacuum inside the ship would cause a total electrical failure. The nav computers will fry!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: We'll lose all control. We won't be able to fire the engines to capture Mars orbit.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: It's already starting. The primary L- 1 hub has been smashed. The systems are crashing.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Everybody switch to suit oxygen. We beat this in the simulator, we can do it here. Jim, you've got the ship. I'm going EVA.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: C'mon, people, let's go! Let's work the problem!

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Jesus, it's still bleeding.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Keep the pressure on!

Speaker: computer
Dialogue: Eighty percent atmosphere...

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Jim, you've gotta get your spare helmet from storage.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: No time. Phil, can you keep the nav computers on-line?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: I can't get this damn machine to re- initialize! And the automated systems just went down. We can't shut down the hab rotation from here.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I'll do it from below.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: We're losing pressure. You could embolize.

Speaker: computer
Dialogue: Seventy percent atmosphere...

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Jim, I've got an idea. If you guys can save enough atmosphere, I'll disconnect the power in the main computer bay, then jump start the systems. I'll do a hard boot.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Has that ever been tested?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Are you kidding? These machines are much too valuable.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Do it.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Jim, how we doin' on the AG?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Just one goddamn second. Come on, c'mon...

Speaker: computer
Dialogue: Voice print identification.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: McConnell!

Speaker: computer
Dialogue: Accepted. Shutting down artificial gravitational rotation.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Hang on!

Speaker: computer
Dialogue: Sixty per cent atmosphere...

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I've got a better idea.  Stay there!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Jesus, uh, OK, this is gonna be like searching for a needle in a haystack.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Shake out the liquid.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Jim, I don't --

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Shake it out near the hull!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: C'mon, c'mon, where are you...?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Woody, the breech is in sector four! Sector four, copy that?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Sonofabitch. You never did that in the simulator.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Where are you, you little bastard, where are you...?

Speaker: computer
Dialogue: Forty percent atmosphere...

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Whoa.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Gotcha!

Speaker: computer
Dialogue: Thirty percent atmosphere...

Speaker: computer
Dialogue: Twenty percent atmosphere...

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: OK... OK now...

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Come on. Come on...!

Speaker: computer
Dialogue: Twenty percent atmosphere...

Speaker: computer
Dialogue: Pressure stabilizing... Atmosphere level increasing.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Yes! Awriiiight! Had it all the way. Yes!

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Shit!

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Get back in here, guys!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Jim, there's a lot of scarring... I'd better check for other punctures while I'm out here.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Copy, I'm heading there now.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Hey, Beautiful...

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Know what? You've got enough left.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Piece of cake?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Well. Easier than the cha-cha.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: I don't know what you're getting so cocky about. We scored better times in the sim at least twice.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: How's his hand?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Seems OK. Couple of the tendons are going to be a little tight for awhile. Try to close your fingers, Phil, nice and slowly.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Well, at least I'll still be able to drive.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: OK, we're ready to light this candle. Go/No Go for braking burn and MOI. Engines?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Go.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Systems.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Go.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Nav.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Go.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: We are Go for the burn. I'm fueling the engines.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Four... Three...

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Jim?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Let's go to Mars.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: What the --

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Shut down engines!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Engines negative! No response! I've got no attitude control!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Manual separation! Blow the bolts!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Negative! The CM doesn't have enough thrust to correct this rotation!

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: We're too steep! Falling into the atmosphere...!

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Christ, at this angle we'll burn up!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: How much time've we got?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: I don't know! Three minutes? I don't know!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Where's the REMO?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: The Resupply Module? Why? That's not --

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Where is it?!

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Uh, it's close...

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Damn it, how close?!

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: I-I don't know. It'll take time...

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: We don't have time! Figure it out! Now!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Jim, we're dead stick, there's no way to maneuver this ship into a link-up!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Not the ship. Just us. We have to go EVA.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: You want us to transfer in suits?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Jesus, Jim -- if we don't make it -- if we miss the REMO...

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: There's no other choice! Phil, how close?!

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: One kilometer, that's the best I can do!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Prepare to abandon ship.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: On my mark, seven percent left thruster. Three, two, one, fire.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Okay. Let's go.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: What're you looking for?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Earth.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Hey. When we get back? We really will have to try this in the sim.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: How we doin' on fuel, Woody?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: I'm at fifty percent.  But I don't see the REMO.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: There she is!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Jesus. She's not where I thought she'd be.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: We're going to miss her.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: We can't catch it. Not like this.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Use the tether.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: We'll only have one, maybe two shots before she's out of reach.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: It'll be better if I leave you the gun while I run out to the REMO. I've got enough fuel left for that.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: You'll be going too fast.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: I'll aim to overshoot, then brake like hell; arc it in.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Seeya in a few.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Okay. I'm on path to overshoot. I'm gonna take the edge off.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: I'm out. Coming in hot. Still long.  Abandoning the unit. I'll brake with suit jets.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Oh Jesus. Jesus...

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Suit jets gone. But I'm gonna make contact...

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: At what velocity?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Impact's gonna be a little rough.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: At what velocity?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Thirty-two.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I'm gonna use the gun to slow you.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: No! You slow me and I'll fall short.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: It's too fast, Woody.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: No choice. I'll be okay. Here we go...

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Woody!!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Woody, what's your status?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Uh, well, no suit jets and I'm still carrying a good deal of velocity.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: As soon as we get hooked up, I'll come get you.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Uh, I'd have to say negative on that, Jim.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Negative on the transmission?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: No, I heard you. Negative on the maneuver. I am not retrievable.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Woody, that's not possible. You're not going that fast.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: It comes down to the amount of fuel, honey. The suit jets were designed for attitude control, not travel. Retrieval just won't work.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: It has to work!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Hey, believe me, I don't like it any more than you do.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Woody --

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Run the numbers, Jim.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Woody, you hang tight. We'll get into the REMO, fire her up, drop her into a lower orbit and come scoop you up.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Sounds good, Jim.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: It's gonna take half an hour to get the REMO reoriented! Woody'll be... He'll be in the atmosphere by then!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Then we'll have to get her moving faster.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: We don't have time!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: You listen to Jim, honey. It's a good plan.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: No! We are going to --

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Oh Jesus, look! The ship!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Look out!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Brakes!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Okay, let's get inside! Phil, start dumping the cargo, or there won't be room for us.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: But we need those supplies for --

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Dump the cargo. Hang on, Woody!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Will do, Jim.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Hey, Beautiful...

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Terri, no!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Goddammit, Terri, it won't work!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Terri, what are you doing?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I'll tell you what I'm not doing, Woody. I'm not going to watch you die.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Terri --

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: You'd do the same for me.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Get inside. Dump the cargo, then start the systems.  Now.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: No. I wouldn't come for you. Not if it just wasn't possible.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I can do it!

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: No, Terri, you can't! You don't have enough fuel to get me, stop us both, and get us back. Hell, you come any farther and you won't have enough to get back yourself.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Listen to me, goddammit! You have to stop! You have to stop now!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: He's right, Terri... It's no use.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Okay, honey...? You gotta go back now.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: The hell I do.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I'm gonna jet a little closer and try again.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Terri, you spend any fuel getting closer, you won't get back, and if anyone tries to get you, they'll die too.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: Honey, please go back. Go back and help everyone get down to the surface.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I am not losing you.

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: I can't let you do it. I can't. I'm sorry.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Woody...?

Speaker: woody
Dialogue: I love you, Terri. God how I love you.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Woody, nooooooo...!!!

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Woody, oh Woody, please God, no!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Come back, Terri.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: He's gone.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Please, Terri...  We need you.

Speaker: new capcom
Dialogue: Okay, they're Go for the burn and MOI. Should be initiating the burn just about... now.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Phil?  Hey, Phil...?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: We're going in blind. We'll deploy the chutes by laptop. I need to get on the data bus, put in a software patch, and try to soften this tin can's landing. I could use your help with the patch.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: That's great. Good job.  Hey, Terri, I was wondering. Think maybe we could rig some kind of seatbelts out of those cargo straps?

Speaker: new capcom
Dialogue: Ray...? We've got some new data, just coming in.

Speaker: new capcom
Dialogue: We just -- it doesn't make any sense. We're not sure how to read this.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Data?

Speaker: new capcom
Dialogue: Yes sir. Telemetry reports the REMO has left its orbit and reached the Martian surface.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: Crashed?

Speaker: new capcom
Dialogue: No sir. Under power.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: new capcom
Dialogue: Sixty-three minutes after Mars Recovery went off-line. Sir, the graph reads like a controlled descent. But that doesn't make any --

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: They used the REMO as a lander.

Speaker: beck
Dialogue: It's McConnell, it's got to be! Nobody else could have pulled this off. Son of a bitch! They're alive.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Better?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Damn right.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Terri, let's see if that oxygen still is operational. Phil, you better check out the ERV. I'll take the Hab. If you find Luke's --

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Just keep in touch.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I'm at the main airlock door.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Entering Hab.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: I've got ERV access. I'm going in. Terri, you okay?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Yeah. This is gonna take awhile to get back to 100% capacity.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: ERV appears structurally intact. Computers are fried, just as we thought.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Copy that. I've got busted filters here, clogged intakes. Helluva cleanup job, but so far no major damage.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I'm in the greenhouse. You better... you better come see this for yourselves.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Jim...?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Luke, it's me! Jim McConnell!

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: You're not here!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Luke, it's Jim!

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: No, no, you're not... you can't be here.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Your wife is Debra! Your son is Bobby! You were reading Treasure Island with him...!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Don't hurt him!

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Phil... Terri...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Jim... I don't understand. You're not supposed to be here... Why are you here? Where's Woody?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: He didn't make it Luke.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Oh no.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Luke, what happened here?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: We fired the radar. It came. They all died.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: What came?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: They all died, but I was spared. Why? Had to be for a reason. Then, all of a sudden, I knew why I was spared.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: So somebody would be left to figure out the secret.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Luke, we still don't understand.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Come. Comecomecome.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Is it just me? Or is he about two mealpacks short of a picnic?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Long term exposure to low gravity can have an adverse impact on the brain. He could be suffering from a form of asphyxia.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Or maybe his whole crew died and he's been marooned alone on Mars. Let's give him time to adjust.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Greatgreatgreat.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: So... let me be sure I understand this. Your ship blew up, with all its supplies. Then you emptied the cargo out of the REMO, and it was totalled on landing. You've got no food, no water, no spare oxygen, nothing but what I see here...?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: What kinda rescue mission is this?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: That kind.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Check it out. New nav boards for the ERV. I got four round-trip tickets, baby, right in here.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Four.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Terri... I'm so sorry. He was a good man.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Thanks, Luke.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: When there's time, we'll talk.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: This way.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: ...When I came to and dug myself out of the sand, my faceplate was cracked. Leaking badly. I barely made it back to Base. It was weeks before I could work up the nerve to go back out there and look for their...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Renee was the only one I could find. But it didn't seem right, somehow, to dig just one grave.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Has it been blowing like this for a while?  We saw a big storm from space. But Micker said it was turning south.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: If it holds course.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: This -- whatever it was -- this force. You say it came directly out of the top of the mountain?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: You don't believe me. That's okay. But I'm not crazy, Jim.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: What did you mean by its "secret?" What secret?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: You better see for yourselves.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: See, where they made their mistake was, they must've planned for it to be visible from Earth...

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Who's "they"?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Don't you understand? Hundreds of millions of years have gone by. You've got erosion, sand storms, lava flows, meteor impacts -- hell, in that much time, the whole surface would've changed. So no wonder we never saw it before. Well, I mean, we saw it, but not like they meant us too. Too much dirt on it.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Saw what?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: This.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Jesus...

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: What is that...?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: I don't know. But whatever it is, somebody built it. And not us.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: What about the sound? That signal you heard before the explosion?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Good, Jim, good. That's the key.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Hear the pauses? That's what made me realize it's a pattern -- a repeating pattern.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Mathematical?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: That's what I thought. There are distinct blocks in the pattern, and within each block the tones come in groups of three. Threethreethree. For months I struggled to analyze it, trying different constructs... Then I thought about dimensions.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: X-Y-Z coordinates...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Right! Three groups equals three dimensions... So I tried assigning different graphic values to each block, group and tone. And finally I got... this.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: My God... Is that what I think it is?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: DNA... that's a model of DNA!

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: You see it, too. Thank God. I was afraid I was just suffering from a form of asphyxia.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: So, okay, so -- somebody left this thing here, somebody -- other than human. But what the hell is it?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: My guess is, it's a signature. A self-portrait of whatever species created the Face.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: But that DNA looks human.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: No way. It's missing the last pair of chromosomes. See?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Yeah, but it's close. Damn close.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: The difference between a man and an ape is less than three percent of genetic material. But that three percent gives you Mozart. Einstein.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Or Jack the Ripper.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: It's been a long day. Let's get a couple hours sleep, then tackle this thing when we're fresher. Phil, your first priority will be to get the motherboards over to the ERV. Concentrate on getting communications up first.  Soon as we've got the juice, we'll send a packet to Micker, tell them Luke's OK, and that... everything else that's happened. The rest of us will take an inventory of supplies, see where we stand. Okay?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: C'mon. There's a pair of scissors in my medkit.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: How do you feel?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Like I just got back my other three percent.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: The backup generator is salvageable, and two of the solar panels. I'm pretty sure I can get the oxygen still back into production, too. So we're not in such bad shape, considering.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Good work, Terri.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Look at that. Phil's idea of absolute essentials.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: It's not a signature.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: That noise from the Face... It's not a signature. It's a test.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: It's asking us for the right answer. It wants us to put in the missing pair of chromosomes.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: But why?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: To prove that we're human.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: We fired radar into that thing. Concentrated sound waves...

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Which it interpreted as a wrong answer... Yes! It's like a, a security alarm. When it gets an incorrect response, it defends itself.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: So what happens when it gets the right answer?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Can you work this the other way? Figure out which tones would be equivalent to the missing chromosomes? Then dub them into your recording of the signal?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: I think so, yes.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: What about the radar gun? Will it accept that input? Can we transmit a completed signal back to the Face?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Whoa, whoa, hold on, Jim. What if you're wrong? Whoever goes out there... I mean, what if you're wrong? Three people have already died over that thing.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Four.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Terri, if we leave here without getting some answers, they all died in vain.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: We just don't know enough about that -- that thing out there to take any more chances.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: What are we here for, if not to take chances...?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: This means we're not alone. It means we're on the brink of the greatest discovery in mankind's history. But we've still got to prove it. Who knows when someone else will get back here? Or if they ever will? You know what Congress is like. They'll say it's too dangerous, too much loss of life, let's go back to unmanned flights. We could be the last explorers to come here for decades. We're it, guys.  We're it.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: We don't have to go out there. There's a better way.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Checking video feed...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: There!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: How close do we need to get?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: I'm not sure. Maybe we better stop by that boulder.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Oh my God...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: It worked... It worked!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Check for radiation.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Normal. Seismic... normal. Anemometer steady. No sign of the vortex.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: I don't know what we did, but guys -- does that look to you like a hostile gesture?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: No. More like an invitation.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Or another test...

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Luke, the four-man rover. Does it still work?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: How long before it hits?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: An hour? Maybe less.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: How bad?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: A storm like that? It could go planetary. And last a year.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: It'll sock us in, Jim. We won't be able to take off. If that happens, with what few supplies we've got left...? We'll starve to death.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Phil, how much longer to prep the ERV?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Maybe forty-five minutes. It'll be tight, but we can make it.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Then there's still time for us to get out there and back.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Stay here. Continue the repair. If something goes wrong, you get out of here before that storm hits.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Go back... alone?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: If we're not back in forty-five minutes, I want you to prep and launch.  That's 1950 hours.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Jim --

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: It's not a suggestion, it's an order. You understand?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: I understand. But --

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: You understand what?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: If you're not back by 1950, I prep and launch.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Let's go.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Phil, do you read me?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Yeah, Jim. Your signal's breaking up a little in the storm, but I read you.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: We're at the Face. We're gonna need a few minutes here. Same deadline, launch at 1950. With or without us. Do you copy?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Copy that.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Jim, are you sure you want to do this?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I'm not sure of anything anymore. But I didn't come a hundred million miles just to turn back in the last ten feet.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Surface seems firm and level.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Roger that. Texture is smooth.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I've got good footing and no obstructions. Let's check our --

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: It's solid again! We're trapped.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Don't move! Keep this orientation.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Phil? Phil, can you still hear me?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Computers are online! Ready to load software. But guys -- we're losing visibility here.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Guys...? Jim? Luke? Terri? Is anyone there...?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Don't leave me.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Jim, what're you doing? You'll depressurize!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I don't think so.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Jim, seal it!

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: No. That was air going into my suit, not out. Look at your own suits -- they're not rigid anymore. We've got pressure in here.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Above Mars atmospheric? That's impossible.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: We're millions of miles from Earth and we're inside a gigantic white face. What's impossible?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: There's six psi in here...  Nitrogen and oxygen.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Otherwise known as air?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Hey, there may be some lethal trace gasses I haven't picked up yet, or... or... oh, the hell with it.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Is that what I think it is?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Yeah. It's Mars.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Oh my God.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Earth, when it was still Pangaea. Before the continents separated.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: They're us. We're them...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: We're Martians...?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: That's what she means.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Oh my God. The Cambrian explosion.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Almost six hundred million years ago, there was a sudden expansion of life on Earth. The first multi-celled plants and animals appeared. No one has ever understood why...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: They seeded Earth.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: ...in, please. Can you... me?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Phil, we're here! We read you.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Thank God! Listen, this storm is really --  You've gotta get back to the ship!

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Phil? Phil...?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: We are in a ship. This is a ship. And the countdown has already started.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: He's right.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Then let's get the hell out of here!

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Jim...

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Jim, we gotta go.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I'm not coming with you.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: What are you talking about? We've got to get home.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: That's where I'm going. Don't you see? That's what all this is for.  You were right Terri. This is an invitation. To follow them. To follow them home.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I have to go. This is the mission now. To find out who we are. Isn't that why we came here? Like Maggie said, "To stand on a new world and look beyond it to the next one."

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: You know, when you think about it -- I wasn't even supposed to be here -- all the accidents, everything that got us to this point, it's just... it's just... I just know it's right.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: I'm okay. I know what I'm doing. But you're running out of time. You've gotta get back to the ERV and get off this planet. Now please go.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: I once felt like I was taking your turn. But now I think maybe you're taking mine. Guess I'm a little jealous.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Thanks for saving my life.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: My pleasure.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I wish Woody were here to see this. He would've wanted to go too, Jim.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: He's here, Terri. We wouldn't have made it without him.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Take care, Jim.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Hey, Jim...?

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Have a great ride.

Speaker: mcconnell
Dialogue: Always do.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Phil? Phil, do you read?  He's not reading.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I can barely read you. Let's get the hell out of here!

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Is anyone there? Can anyone read me?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I've lost the Base Camp beacon!

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: No good! We're driving blind.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: I'll try to keep on a straight line! It's our only chance.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Don't worry! I've worked with Phil for four years! I know Jim gave him a direct order, but he won't leave without us.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: This is ERV, do you read? ERV to Rover, do you read...?

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: This is ERV, do you read?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Save the fuel, Phil. We're coming in.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Uh, Phil's not here right now. He left for Earth five minutes ago. Please leave your message at the beep.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Where's Jim?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: He got another ride.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Tell you on the way. Let's go!

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Dear God. Look at that.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Is that him?

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Godspeed Jim McConnell.
